abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            are substantial. Lessons suggest the following. The Bank
            should consider including in its legal covenants, provisions
            which would avoid delaying project components if the
            government chooses to substitute certain project activities
            with grant funds, which had not yet been approved, nor
            received. Therefore, the lack of grant money will not be a
            factor delaying the execution of important project
            components. In a small developing country striving to emerge
            from poverty, with very limited capacity, it is unrealistic
            to expect transformation of the financial sector into
            institutional framework models that enable private sector
            investment, all in a relatively short timeframe; rather, a
            longer time-frame should be expected. Further lessons
            address the need to design privatization programs in a
            socially sensitive manner, e.g., by including in enterprise
            sale contracts, clauses to protect workers and minority
            investors; a technical assistance operation can be effective
            and quickly disbursed if a previous lending operation, or
            set of actions had already laid the ground for its prompt
            implementation; and, project ownership and commitment is
            critical to project success, in this case the task team
            worked to ensure a consistent level of involvement of the
            Government in project supervision, and monitoring.
